article.description:
Minnesota's practice habits carried over into
its season opener Sunday. And that's not necessarily a compliment.
article.headline: Rickert's 26 points pace Gophers
article.linkText: Minnesota starts fast, hangs on to beat UNC-Asheville
article.story:
MINNEAPOLIS (AP) -- Minnesota's practice habits carried over into
its season opener Sunday. And that's not necessarily a compliment.

	   Rick Rickert scored 26 points and Maurice Hargrow added a
career-high 21 as the 24th-ranked Golden Gophers built a big
first-half lead and held on for an 87-81 victory over
UNC-Asheville.

	   Gophers coach Dan Monson and his players admitted that they tend
to start strong in practices and finish poorly. And that's exactly
what happened Sunday.

	   The Gophers, who were ranked in the preseason for the first time
in six years, led by 23 in the first half, only to have Asheville
outscore them 54-37 in the second half.

	   ''Honestly, it felt like we lost,'' Rickert said. ''Our
intensity has to pick up and carry through the whole game.''

	   Rickert, last season's Big Ten freshman of the year, went
5-for-6 from 3-point range and also played strong perimeter defense
to help the Gophers improve to 4-0 in season openers under Monson.

	   Andre Smith had 27 points to lead Asheville (0-2), which also
played well against Michigan State on Friday before losing 66-52.

	   ''It's good to know that we can play with them,'' Smith said.
''We just have to put two halves of basketball together.''

	   Against the Gophers, Asheville trailed 82-66 when it put
together a 13-3 run. But Hargrow made two foul shots for Minnesota,
and the Bulldogs managed just two more points.

	   Still, there wasn't much celebration afterward among the
Gophers.

	   ''The second half, they outworked us. A lot of guys are
disappointed in themselves,'' Rickert said.

	   Michael Bauer finished with 20 points for Minnesota, which
finished last season 18-13 and lost to Richmond in the second round
of the NIT.

	   The Bulldogs were able to cut into the deficit because of poor
free-throw shooting by the Gophers, who developed a reputation last
season for blowing late leads. Minnesota shot 23 of 40 from the
line and was outrebounded 42-35.

	   Despite the close call, Bauer said he never felt the win was in
doubt. But ''If they had about five more minutes, yeah,'' he said.
''Just because we have so much talent, we were able to hold them
off.''

	   Early on, the Gophers frustrated Asheville with a trapping
defense, forcing the Bulldogs into shooting just under 35 percent
in the first half; overall, Asheville committed 15 turnovers.

	   ''I just wish we could've been able to finish it off a little
better,'' Bauer said.

	   Minnesota scored plenty from the outside early, with Rickert and
Bauer combining for five 3-pointers to open the game.

	   Bauer came out aggressively, cutting toward the basket, drawing
fouls and getting physical on defense. The 6-foot-8 junior from
Hastings, Minn., brought the crowd to its feet with a couple of
impressive blocks.

	   With 6:50 left in the first half, Bauer stuffed Smith hard
underneath the basket and sent him to the floor. Then, with 3:43
left in the half, Bauer swatted Oliver Holmes' baseline jumper into
the seats.

	   ''We're a better basketball team than what we were showing,''
Bulldogs coach Eddie Biendenbach said. ''We can't get down by that
many points.''
